Comments_List: The course covered a variety of classic topics in numerical computation, a number of fundamental math concepts needed to understand them as well as useful guidelines on programming.
Numerical techniques and methods, along with their pitfalls.
I learned computer programming, signal processing, linear algebra, differential equations, and applied numeric computing concepts.
Exposure to numerical techniques for integration, diagonalization, linear systems, differential equations, etc. Some good programming advice. Several recyclable anecdotes about life in the USSR.

Strengths: incredibly entertaining professor.
Weaknesses: I literally learned zero things.
The lectures were clear and interesting and organized in a way to teach material that will be useful in a variety of fields and environments.

Strengths: cover a lot of topics
Weakness: hope professor can elaborate on some concepts

Strengths: the material was fascinating and Professor Rokhlin obviously knows it as well as anyone. 

Weaknesses: Absolutely no work at all => no retention of the material. I didn't feel we covered that much, especially since we didn't go that in-depth on the topics we did cover.
I mean, yah. Interesting professor, low work.
Yes absolutely! The material is very interesting and useful, and professor Rokhlin is a great lecturer
I would strongly recommend this course. It'll force you to actually understand linear algebra. His lectures on proper programming technique are very important.

I can't say I would. I love the material and I like and respect Professor Rokhlin, but I wonder if I would have learned just as much from staying home and reading the Wikipedia pages. Having said that, there's literally no downside to taking it except the time spent going to lecture.
